channel.title: Posts on open collector
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on open collector

item.title: Buildlog: A soldering smoke absorber
item.description: This is a fan that takes a carbon filter cartridge. It’s used to redirect the fumes encountered during electronics soldering.

item.title: ESPRESSObin: Moving to OpenWRT
item.description: Backstory: I’ve been maintaining a build of LEDE for the ESPRESSObin single board computer. Things have changed for the better, so its now time to sunset the build.

item.title: Bug Hunting (in Fedora's KiCad)
item.description:
This is a bit of a departure from the usual content here! I spent a bit more time than I should have piecing all of this together, so i’m collecting all of the knowledge that I needed to solve it.

It’s presented intuitively here, so you can see how I lept to the conclusion that I did.

item.title: Cases for Feathers
item.description: These are 3D printable cases for Adafruit’s Feather series of development boards. They’re designed to be compact, unobtrusive and adaptable from prototyping to deployment.

item.title: A modular Pi camera enclosure
Electroscope update
item.description: The 9V attachable electroscope has been updated. The silkscreened date on the back for this version is 2014-08-24(!)

item.title: CR2032 tester
Toy Electroscope
Avrrrinator B Released
Panasonic PIR Breakout Board
Avrrrinator Rev. A Updated
Stop, blink and roll*
item.description: A little bit of the cat got out of the bag some time ago: You’re looking at ~24 hours of continuous AVR flashing compressed down into 6 seconds. While I won’t be releasing the connecting PCB just yet (i’m still beating down a few issues and refining the BOM), I thought it would be good to supply the scripts I used to do the actual time lapse since it was non-obvious from a “oh dear, the contest entry is due in <48 hours isn’t it.

item.title: Hardware Volume Controller
item.description: (5/11/13) - Hey fantastic reader: This is an old how-to (from 4/2/12!) that existed in its own self-contained repository. Reflecting back, this hack was kind of silly, but i’m porting it here to keep everything in one place. And if you’re curious about the long-term viability of this build.. it is still kicking. The detents are a little less crisp now, but everything works a treat. (And now, back to your regularly scheduled post re-run!

item.title: Tools for 3D Printing: What do I get?
Printable divider for the 10164 storage drawer
item.description: This is a 3D printable small drawer divider for the Akro-Mils 10164 parts cabinet. The clear drawers themselves have a nice little slot for partitioning, so this divider fits right in and sits snugly without bowing out the drawer. While there are several dividers that come attached to the back of the cabinet (which are manually de-paneled by the end consumer), they’re very limited in quantity. So if you have a 3D printer of some sort, or want to play with the model enough to make it ‘go’ on a laser cutter/CNC, give this a shot.

item.title: The Avrrrinator (Revision A)
3D Printed Bus Pirate v3.6 Case (DP6037)
item.description: Source files and general instructions for printing can be found here. The Bus Pirate is a pretty fantastic device for sniffing around and working with new circuits. It can even act as an AVR programmer. After using one to fiddle with a few circuits, a case became necessary after seeing its value. While there are cases that can be purchased[1], a 3D printer was laying around waiting to be used.

GPS module connected to a Raspberry Pi (for accurate time keeping):

item.title: AVR Programming with Adafruit's Atmega32u4
item.description:
Introduction

This guide will help you build your own LUFA AVRISP-MKII clone using the Adafruit Atmega32u4 breakout board.

item.title: music
item.description:
A bit of Ruby to start things off (I guess I should say ‘test’ in here too).

#!/usr/bin/env ruby

class Music
  attr_accessor :id, :artist, :title, :album
end

songs = Array.new

ARGV.each do |m|
  f = File.open(m)
  while (l = f.gets)
    info = l.split(';')

    if info.length > 0
      song = Music.new
      song.id = info[0]
      song.title = info[1]
      song.artist = info[2]
      song.album = info[3]
      songs << song
    end
  end
  f.close()
end

songs.each do |s|
  puts "#{s.artist} - #{s.title} - #{s.album}"
end
